												Take part Mass Effect, part Halo, and throw in a dash of Star Wars and you get Advent Rising. This is the utmost praise, however, as Advent Rising is a fantastic game. It is clear that Mass Effect borrowed heavily from this game as the Geth seem to be ripped straight from it. The fiction behind the story is some of the most engrossing sci-fi I've seen in a while, which is no surprise since it was written by Orson Scott Card.The gameplay is third-person, with the use of guns and special powers. The guns do feel really nice, but I found myself using the powers more often, especially in the later game. The level design is superb as well, and I never felt lost, even in some of the bigger environments.The game is not without it's faults, however. Consulting  PC Gaming Wiki [pcgamingwiki.com] is a must for essential fixes, but I still had a fair number of issues. There were graphic anomalies when things got intense and there were lots of explosions. cutscenes would sometimes hicup as well, although the dialogue did not skip. The most annoying thing were the game crashes which happened a handful of times. Thankfully, the game saved at the exact point of the crash so nothing was lost, but still annoying.Iffy port aside, this game is fantastic. It really is a shame we will probably never see the planned sequels as this game builds a very promising lore and world around it. It's certainly worth playing, just know that it will probably never get a proper finale.

												Advent Rising is a game that I randomly found. I saw many steam reviews saying that it was one of their favourite games of all time. And had a person in my steam friend list who also was super excited about it. So, I recently played the game to find out if it was all nostalgia or if it really is a masterpiece.You start the game off by getting on to a spaceship and receiving your training. You visit an alien form that warns you of another alien group that is about to attack. When you return to the ship it is under attack and you have to escape. I have to say the first 2 hours of the game really felt boring to me. The gameplay felt like you were just going from room to room killing aliens. The only positive was that you have choices in the beginning. Which you, sadly and strangely, don't have as you continue further into the game. After those initial 2 hours it finally starts to get interesting. Also your weapons are levelling up and you are unlocking new cool powers (It comes over weird in the story that you randomly unlock new powers though). The game has so many powers and weapons that I haven't been able to try them all out. This may be because you are limited to one weapon or power per hand. Also, I have to say that the end bosses were pretty challenging overall, I wasn't expecting that. The driving sections in the game can become really exciting, except if you have to shoot. In the end the game took me 10 hours to complete on normal difficulty.The story is pretty well written and had me coming back to the game. I am sometimes amazed that they actually did what they did with the story. I reached a part of the game that made me wish to stop playing, but the story helped me push through it. There are times when the story felt cheesy and cheap (And sadly the not CGI cutscenes looked really poor). It is also obvious that the screenwriting took inspiration from movies popular at the time of the game's release. The game has many slow-motion animations while jumping or finishing an enemy to make it more cinematic. This is pretty cool but after a while it can be really irritating, because you are just waiting for the animation to end.The sound design of the game sadly feels strangely rushed. There are too many instances to list: The game is missing walking and explosion sounds and there are a lot of other strange audio issues. Such as an NPC having the same voice as the protagonist when they get hit. The soundtrack on the other hand is really great and done by a real orchestra. The Graphics thanks to the style and can look really great, but sadly the textures mostly look bland. ( I had that the game crashed several times, and sadly it never putted me at the last checkpoint. )I would recommend if you play this game:To use the  Advent Revising Mod [www.miketyndall.com]Turn off auto-aimingFinal thoughts:I think it is sad that Advent Rising is a forgotten game. The game was much too rushed in production and had a boring beginning and ending. However, I still think that if you can accept the complaints there is a great experience to be had in the game.

												Advent Rising is one of these games that just can't seem to get it all together. Despite excellent production values and a compelling sci-fi story there are some less-than-perfect gameplay flaws that mar what could have been one of the best games of the year.Advent Rising tells the futuristic tale of Gideon Payne, an altruistic hero and rookie pilot that attempts to save all humans from an evil alien race. The Seekers are hell bent on destroying the humans that colonized the galaxy while another benevolent race revere the humans to be fantastical creatures with extraordinary gifts. In Gideon's case this turns out to be true as he is imbued with superhuman powers such as levitation, energy blasts and energy shields.An action-based shooter, Advent Rising incorporates elements of role-playing in that you unlock new skills, powers and weapons and increase your ability to utilize them in different situations. This game has already been released on the Xbox where the control system attempts to replicate the keyboard and mouse combo of the PC. Now that it's been released on the PC these features are somewhat redundant. Some of the technical problems that plagued the Xbox version have been addressed such as the chugging framerate which is as smooth as glass on the PC but there are other problems that keep this game from reaching the top of the heap.This isn't your typical shooter. It's marinated in a good story, good graphics(keeping in mind it came out in 2005), great effects and an excellent soundtrack produced by two Emmy award winners. The story was written by Orson Scott Card who was responsible for Halo as well as other sci-fi publications. Playing the game on the PC it seems to have more console elements to it. It's reminiscent of a console to PC port such as Max Payne. Not only do the main characters share the same last name they also use a dodge move that slows down time. It's called bullet time in case you just fell off of the turnip wagon.The pace is a little slower than your average shooter but that's because of the all-encompassing storyline. It justifies situations in the game. There are lots of interesting plot twists and turns. It's like a great comic book come to life. It's just too bad there are some control issues. Some of the weapons are slow such as the plasma and rockets. Character models are irregularly elongated and have a spongy bounce to their movements which doesn't feel very solid. There are also instances where characters get stuck in the environment.The voiceacting and soundtrack are second to none. The music doesn't just mimic the action it actually foreshadows events in true Hollywood fashion. There is some cornball dialog that seems like it came from an anime production but thankfully those moments are few and far between. The explosions are impressive from both a visual and audio standpoint. They almost set a new standard, which is good considering that some of the graphics are rather boring, especially some of the overused textures.Advent Rising is a good game, it's short but it's good. There are some flaws that you need to overlook but there's nothing here that will ruin the entire experience. The lack of a co-op or multi-player modes reduces the replay value but you can go back and experiment with different combinations of powers.

												I am legitimately surprised, but this is actually a really fun game. As I recall, it was supposed to be a "halo killer" back in the days when games didn't just crank out sequel after sequel after sequel (yes i'm conscious of megaman and final fantasy) and effectively kill themselves from a lack of innovation, but it's got a decent identity of its own and it's just straight up fun to play. Lots of frantic action, intuitive controls on PC, lots of big booms, and a big boobed damsel in distress. Or something.I think one of the things I like most about it is that it's a relic from an era before every shooter became obsessed with pseudo-rpg elements like leveling up and gaining XP. Advent Rising has weapon proficiencies, but they're almost unnoticeable and are kind of just a vague foreshadowing of the direction the genre would eventually head.It's far from perfect (respawning enemies, lots of crashing, still honestly a pretty blatant attempt to capitalize on halo's popularity, written by that dumb mormon gay-basher that nerds jerk off to all the time) but it's some of the most fun I've had so far since I started this whole mess. 												An old game, sometimes doesn't agree with steam, but a good game.The storytelling is a little awkward with rapid jumps in time, introducing new powers with the same animation makes them seem a little less important, and you're regularly thrown into new environments that you become a little shell shocked to the ambiance - and likely can't appreciate the fullest of the worldbuilding. Similarly, the controls are a little awkward at certain points. I don't mind dual wielding rifles, given the statements about recoil in this universe - but more importantly, the Throw ability is a little hard to use. Normally I wouldn't complain, since there are many otehr abilities that work without flaw - but the Throw ability is used in a number of boss fights.Now, even with all of that? I enjoyed myself.It was a unique narrative, in a unique world. A lot of different faces, mixed characters, some of whom I grew attached to more than others. The deaths of characters stood out to me, and though I wish there was more choice - I can safely say that this game doesn't parade behind an Illusion of Choice system. When you have to make a choice, which may be rare - but given this game's age I can understand that - you still greatly appreciate the results of your choice.Combat is interesting, and but not a change of pace from the usual archetypals. It's relatively smooth to go and decide what you want to equip, though knowing how much more XP you need to level a skill requires going through multiple menus. Having said this, I really like one thing about this game: You cannot max everything. I do not think, unless you play on easy, and grind away at mobs tirelessly, will you max all of your skills. That makes your gameplay choices a little more meaningful, and my character reflected it.In short? Yes, some of the voice acting isn't great. Its an old game. It can be clunky in some places, but all in all - I recommend fans of High Science Fiction pick it up. We'll never see a sequel, but we can smile at what was Advent.

												Advent Rising is one of those games that tries to tell a very good story behind some relatively good 3rd person dodge shooters with some fancy-shmancy powers. The result is a bit of a mixed bag though, but for a 10 year old game it held up pretty well. Unfortunately, the game is sort of a sleeper hit that never was popular enough to finish the other two games in the trilogy. The story penned by Orson Scott Card (Ender's Game, etc.) has the Wyeth Brothers (you control Gideon, the younger brother) be the pilot taking the ambassador to a first contact with a race of aliens who worship the humans almost as Gods, and they bear bad news... while they are perfectly peaceful... their enemies, known as the Seekers, are about to wipe out all the humans, and they will be here in days. And just as the shuttle head back for home, the Seekers arrived early with a full fleet, and started to invade the human space station. Fighting through the chaos and waves of aliens cutting through the hull and marines defending till the last, Gideon witness the Seekers appear to be scanning humans as they execute them. He was able to get his brother to escape pod, but his fiancee Olivia had been captured or lost. Pod landed on the planet, but there's full enemy action there too. Fighting through more enemies, they arrive at the city, fought through more enemies, reached the general in charge, but was told they need to find a ship off the planet... Seekers are using asteroids... any one not getting off are dead. As the asteroid bombardment begain, Wyeth brothers have to run through a collapsing base to locate the last available ship... Well, I've barely covered 1/3 of the game so far. Later Gideon discovered he has powers that he barely knew how to tap, and with the help of some friendly aliens, he may survive long enough to figure out what is going on... And let's just say there's enough plot twists left and right to keep you guessing. The game itself is third-person with some vehicle sections. Basically you control this guy, very athletic that can jump, pinwheel, dive and roll, and so on. He can also dual-wield two long weapons (or short) and achieve phenomenal accuracy if you lock on to the targets. So the game basically is a lot of shooting and jumping around, even a few fisticuffs when you have no weapons (and later, fight with your powers). The problem is, you only have two active attacks, and if you need a third or a fourth you have to remap them and things get dicey, and in the late game boss fights you will need more than two attacks. Consider this a hint. :)  You do get to drive a vehicle sometimes, and the "Scythe" is almost a bit like predecessor to HALO's Warthog. Your brother or allies will get in and man the gun for you. And it handles pretty well. It also has a bit of a booster for the more difficult jumps that you may sometimes need to make. And yes, you can run enemies over. Seekers also have hovertanks that you can borrow. There are also sometimes stationary turrets you can appropriate against Seeker gunship/dropships. Graphics is obviously a bit dated by current standards, but not excessively so. Animation is decent, and while architecture is a bit square-ish it's not too bad. Good story, lots of action, though a bit cliche-ish at times. This game really needs a bit of love, even though it's a decade late.

												Rating: 8/10Advent Rising is scifi adventure following a human named Gideon as he teams up humans and aliens alike to combat one of the most powerful forces in the galaxy. In this epic scifi story many aliens hold humans at a near god-like stature and have been on the search for them for many years believing that they posess vast powers. The aliens find the humans just in time to warn them of a major threat that is heading there way and could be the end of the human race.The story in Advent Rising is nothing short of excellent. I bought this game on sale and did not expect to play for very long, 3 days later I have completed the game. The story is just that entertaining. Each section leaves you wanting to see more of the story unfold. You are in for a treat with this one.While the overall gameplay is that of an early 2000s game (which this game is) the combat is very addicting. You will be using melee, a huge variety of guns and even special abilities you unlock which are very fun to play with. There is nothing like throwing an enemy into the depth of space using your telekinitic-like abilities or boxing an enemy inside a forcefield and watching them kill themselves. You can also control turrets, drive land and flying vehicles all with their own weapons and abilities. The boss fights each have a specific strategy and it can provide quite the challenge to figure out.The game is not without its flaws though. While the combat is addicting, the style in which the enemies approach is very repatitive and sometimes the targeting system will work against you. I found myself aiming manually as opposed to using the target system due to this. Also the game tends to crash randomly after cutscenes. Luckily the game saves quite frequently so this is not a major issue, but is still rather annoying. There is also one bug where the game can't recognize proper input if you have a game controller in. This is easily remedied by unplugging the controller though.Advent Rising was far more than I expected it to be. It was one of the better stories I have played through this year. The gameplay is repetitive at times but the combat is still very satisfying. There are a few bugs with the game but they are not decision breaking. The story alone in Advent Rising is worth the full price tag. If you find it on sale it is a steal.

												We are all entitled games that suck but we still love despite their shortcomings. The story behind this game is unsurprisingly good, written by Orson Scott Card (Ender's Game). It was meant to be a trilogy but only got this first installment done due to issues the company had later on.I played this game for the story but I loved the combat system. It combines close combat, guns and magic in such a way that it is completely seemless. The targeting system is a bit troublesome at times.At the time of writing, the game is only 10 dollars and it is well worth it for a decent 20 hour story-based game.
